dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh my god, you're kidding me. Another one of these, like, 'poor rich people' reports? Ugh.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my god, you're kidding me. Another one of these, like, 'poor rich people' reports? Ugh.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, hold on, A. The Capgemini World Wealth Report, um, it actually paints a pretty grim picture.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, hold on, A. The Capgemini World Wealth Report, um, it actually paints a pretty grim picture.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Capgeminis World Wealth Report 2019 shows that the ultra-high-net-worth individual population (defined as having $30 million or more) declined by 4%, and their wealth declined by around 6%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Grim for who, B? Like, the guys who own yachts bigger than my apartment?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Grim for who, B? Like, the guys who own yachts bigger than my apartment?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Actually, yeah. The ultra-high-net-worth people, the thirty-million-dollars-and-up crowd. They saw a four percent dip, their wealth decreased by six percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Actually, yeah. The ultra-high-net-worth people, the thirty-million-dollars-and-up crowd. They saw a four percent dip, their wealth decreased by six percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Capgeminis World Wealth Report 2019 shows that the ultra-high-net-worth individual population (defined as having $30 million or more) declined by 4%, and their wealth declined by around 6%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A dip? Six percent of, what, a billion? Please. My grocery bill went up more than that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A dip? Six percent of, what, a billion? Please. My grocery bill went up more than that.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But that decline, A, accounted for seventy-five percent of the entire global wealth decrease. Seventy-five percent!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But that decline, A, accounted for seventy-five percent of the entire global wealth decrease. Seventy-five percent!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This plunge accounted for 75% of the total global wealth decrease.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what, the rest of us just like, magically got richer then? Or stayed exactly the same?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what, the rest of us just like, magically got richer then? Or stayed exactly the same?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Not exactly. Mid-tier millionaires, five to thirty million, they experienced like, twenty percent of the decline.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not exactly. Mid-tier millionaires, five to thirty million, they experienced like, twenty percent of the decline.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is the biggest section in free-fall with what the report calls mid-tier millionaires (high-net-worth individuals (HNW) with between $5-30 million of wealth) representing 20% of the total decline

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but what about the actual millionaires, the ones who live next door? The normal rich people?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but what about the actual millionaires, the ones who live next door? The normal rich people?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, uh, those with one to five million? They actually experienced the lowest decline. Largely unaffected, the report says.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, uh, those with one to five million? They actually experienced the lowest decline. Largely unaffected, the report says.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the millionaire-next-door segment (who have between $1-5 million of wealth and makes up almost 90% of the HNWI population) remaining the least affected.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Ha! See? So, basically, the people who have so much money they don't even know what to do with it, they lost some. The rest of the rich are totally fine.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ha! See? So, basically, the people who have so much money they don't even know what to do with it, they lost some. The rest of the rich are totally fine.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But the tech sector suffered the most, A. And China, um, trade tensions, accounted for over a trillion dollars in decline in Asia-Pacific alone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the tech sector suffered the most, A. And China, um, trade tensions, accounted for over a trillion dollars in decline in Asia-Pacific alone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The decline in global wealth was driven by China with the Asia-Pacific region representing $1 trillion of the global decline in wealth... The report notes: China alone was responsible for more than half (53%) of Asia-Pacific and more than 25% of global HNWI wealth loss.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, the poor tech bros. My heart bleeds. I bet they're still eating avocado toast though.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, the poor tech bros. My heart bleeds. I bet they're still eating avocado toast though.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Even Europe saw a three percent decline, and the UK, because of Brexit, took a six percent hit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even Europe saw a three percent decline, and the U K, because of Brexit, took a six percent hit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Europe by 3%... HNWI wealth performance in the United Kingdom took a significant hit with a 6% decline. The report adds that UK economic growth is at its lowest point since 2012 in a large part down to, political paralysis triggered by Brexit creating market uncertainty

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Brexit! Of course, blame Brexit for everything. What about the US then? Did we just like, sail through it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Brexit! Of course, blame Brexit for everything. What about the U S then? Did we just like, sail through it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Actually, the US did pretty well. Economic growth, unemployment down, wages up. US HNWIs, um, outperformed others.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Actually, the U S did pretty well. Economic growth, unemployment down, wages up. U S HNWIs, um, outperformed others.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: HNWIs in the United States outperformed those in other developed nations as a result of economic growth US GDP rose by 3% in 2018 compared with 2% in 2017 as unemployment shrank and wages inched upward.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: HNWIs. Right. So, basically, the rich got richer, or at least stayed rich, here. This whole thing just sounds like, um, rich people problems to me.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: HNWIs. Right. So, basically, the rich got richer, or at least stayed rich, here. This whole thing just sounds like, um, rich people problems to me.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However North America was one of three regions to record an increase in HNWI population (0.4%), although HNWI wealth decreased slightly by 1%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But James Barton from Featherstone says the old model, you know, 'equities down, bonds up,' it's not reliable anymore. Assets are correlated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But James Barton from Featherstone says the old model, you know, 'equities down, bonds up,' it's not reliable anymore. Assets are correlated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: James Barton runs the investment arm of the Featherstone family office, he tells Forbes via email, 2018 was a year when both equity markets and bond markets retracted globally, the moth-bitten, backward-looking model of 'Equities go down/Bonds go up' is broken as these asset classes have become correlated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, the poor wealth managers. They'll just figure out a new way to make their clients richer anyway. It's like, a continuous cycle of complaining while swimming in money.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, the poor wealth managers. They'll just figure out a new way to make their clients richer anyway. It's like, a continuous cycle of complaining while swimming in money.
